question: Given standard reduction potentials $\text{Cu}^{2+}/\text{Cu}$ ($+0.34$ V) and $\text{Zn}^{2+}/\text{Zn}$ ($-0.76$ V), compute the standard cell potential rounded to two decimal places; using this result with $R = 8.314\ \text{J/mol}\cdot\text{K}$ and $T = 298\ \text{K}$, determine the equilibrium constant for the spontaneous reaction with $\Delta G^\circ$ rounded to two decimal places. Then, using $\Delta H_f^\circ(\text{Cu}^{2+}, \text{aq}) = +64.77\ \text{kJ/mol}$ and $\Delta H_f^\circ(\text{Zn}^{2+}, \text{aq}) = -153.89\ \text{kJ/mol}$ alongside the determined equilibrium constant, calculate the theoretical temperature in kelvins where $\Delta G^\circ = 0$ for this redox reaction, rounding your final answer to three significant figures.
subject: science
constant_ev: Round the equilibrium temperature calculation to three significant figures (matching K's precision)
derived_ev: The standard enthalpy of formation for Cu²⁺(aq) is +64.77 kJ/mol as confirmed by NIST and CRC Handbook
The standard enthalpy of formation for Zn²⁺(aq) is -153.89 kJ/mol as confirmed by NIST and CRC Handbook
The reaction enthalpy (ΔH°) for the redox reaction is -218.66 kJ/mol
The standard Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) for the galvanic cell reaction is -212273.66 J/mol
The entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction is -21.43 J/mol·K
The theoretical equilibrium temperature (T_eq) where ΔG° = 0 for the spontaneous redox reaction is 10203.50 K
The theoretical equilibrium temperature where ΔG° = 0 for the spontaneous redox reaction is 10200 K

tier1_result.reasoning: The solver's calculations are mathematically correct and, after rounding to three significant figures, the computed T = 10200 K matches the expected answer because standard thermodynamic relationships were applied correctly.
